_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Accident Release Prevention and Response Policies
Twin Eagle Terminals and Logistics (TETL) owns and operates the Twin Eagle rail facility (facility) in Howard County, Colorado.
The facility is designed to transfer butane from railcars to trucks for delivery to end markets.
TETL has a long-standing commitment to workers and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by efforts in accident
prevention, such as training personnel, quality assurance, and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and
maintenance of TETL facilities. TETL policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated
substances. However, if a release does occur, trained TETL personnel plan to evaluate the situation, take actions within the
capabilities of the facility, and notify the necessary outside agencies.
1.1	Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances
Butanes are unloaded from railcars into trucks with an operating capacity of approximately 3,708,400 gallons of flammable chemicals. The
railcars and connected pipelines are considered a single process that has two or more connected vessels of the same
regulated substance that could be involved in a potential release at the facility. Regulated flammable substances (listed in the
40 CFR §68.130) used at the facility are i-Butane, n-Butane, i-Pentane, n-Pentane, 1-Butene, Propane, and Ethane. Since there are different flammable
substances in a single process, this is defined as a flammable mixture. The RMP rule only applies to flammable mixtures if the
amount of a regulated substance in the mixture is greater than one percent (1%) and the mixture as a whole meets the
National Fire Protection Association s 4 rating (NFPA-4) requirements of materials that vaporize quickly or completely when
subjected to normal atmospheric pressure and temperature, are easily dispersed in the air, and burn easily. Typically, this
degree includes materials that will spontaneously ignite wh

en exposed to air, flammable gases, flammable cryogenic
materials, and any liquid or gaseous material that is liquid while under pressure and has a flash point below 73 degrees
Fahrenheit [°F] (22.8 degrees Celsius [°C]) and a boiling point below 100 °F (37.8 °C). The covered process for the mixture of
flammable substances is calculated for a worst-case scenario that involves the flammable mixture substances above the
threshold quantities, greater than 10,000 pounds.
Toxics were not modeled as part of this analysis because the only regulated substances present are i-Butane, n-Butane, i-Pentane, n-Pentane, 1-Butene, Propane, and Ethane, which are not classified as toxic substances.
1.2	General Accident Release Program 3 Prevention Program
1.2.1	Employee Participation
TETL encourages employees to participate in areas of process safety management and accident prevention as follows:
	Updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information
	Performing necessary calculations for Process Safety Management (PSM) and Risk Management Plan (RMP)
	Maintaining good engineering practices
	Participating as a member of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team
Employees have access to information about the accident prevention program.
1.2.2	Process Safety Information
TETL has developed and implemented numerous technical documents to support the safe operation of the facility processes.
These technical documents address:
	Chemical properties and associated hazards
	Necessary block flow diagrams of the process
	Maximum chemical substance inventories
	Upper and lower limits of fixed and rotating process equipment
	Equipment design basis and configuration information
	Adequate information to support good engineering practices
The information referenced above is included in the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA), Standard Operating Procedures (SOP),
and 1910.38 Emergency Action Plan (EAP) provided by TETL.
Chemical-specific information, including hazard and emergency respons

e/exposure considerations, is provided in the chemical
safety data sheets (SDS). For regulated process areas, TETL has documented safety-related limits for specific process
parameters such as temperatures, levels, and composition in the operators' procedures manual. The facility maintains the
process within these limits by using process equipment and monitoring instruments, trained personnel, and protective
instrument systems such as automated shutdown systems.
The facility also maintains numerous technical documents with information about the design and construction of the process
equipment including materials of construction, design pressures, temperature, and electrical ratings. The design and
construction information of the process equipment, in combination with procedures and equipment operating history, provide a
basis for inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes. Process
safety information must be readily accessible to workers and contractors.
1.2.3	Process Hazard Analysis
TETL has a comprehensive program, including a team of personnel, to identify and manage hazards associated with the RMP covered process. This program systematically examines potential hazards and puts equipment in place to manage hazards.
The team identifies, evaluates, and makes recommendations for the management of identified potential hazards. The team's
findings are forwarded to TETL management for resolution. The approved mitigation options in response to the PHA team's
findings are tracked until completion. The ultimate resolution of each finding is documented and retained.
The facility continuously updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results. These continuous reviews are conducted
regularly for at least five years and will be conducted at this frequency until the process is no longer operating. The results and
findings from these updates are documented and retained.
1.2.4	Operating Procedures
TETL maintains written

Operating Procedures for the covered process that address primary operations as mandated by the
Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), good engineering practice,
and manufacturers. These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for
consistent training of new operators. Procedures are continuously reviewed and annually certified by management for
completeness and accuracy. Operating procedures are revised, as necessary, by employee suggestions, compliance audits,
PHAs, good engineering practice, and pre-startup safety reviews (PSSR), to maintain completeness and accuracy. Revisions
are implemented through TETL management.
Process operating procedures are readily available for personnel to use, as necessary, to safely perform their job tasks and
maintain the process unit operations within the defined limits.
1.2.5	Training
TETL has implemented a comprehensive training program for employees involved in operating covered processes at the
facility. New employees receive basic training in process operations if they are not already familiar with such operations. After
completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks. A
performance review must be concluded during this training interval. After the operator demonstrates adequate knowledge to
perform the duties and tasks safely on their own, they are allowed to work independently. In addition, operators continuously
receive subsequent training on the operating procedures to refresh their skills and knowledge to an acceptable level. This refresher training is conducted regularly for at least three years, or more frequently, if deemed necessary. Training is
documented for each operator, including the means used to verify and demonstrate skills.
1.2.6	Contractors
TETL may use contractors to supplement its workforce during intervals of increased maintenance or construc

tion activities.
The facility has procedures in place to train contractors because some contractors work on or near covered process
equipment. The goal of the training is for contractors to:
	Perform their work in a safe manner
	Have the appropriate knowledge and skills
	Be aware of the hazards in their workplace
	Understand what they should do in the event of an emergency
	Understand and follow facility safety rules
	Inform facility personnel of hazards that they find during their work
The bulleted list above is accomplished by providing contractors with:
	Process overviews
	Information about safety and health hazards
	Emergency response plan requirements
	Secure work practices before beginning work
In addition, TETL management evaluates the contractors safety program and performance during the selection of a
contractor. Facility personnel also monitor contractor performance concerning their safety obligations.
1.2.7	Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR)
TETL conducts a PSSR for new facility modifications that require a change in the process safety information. The purpose of
the PSSR is to see that safety features, procedures, personnel, and equipment are appropriately prepared for a startup before
placing the equipment into service. This review provides an additional check that construction is in compliance with the design
specifications and that supporting systems are ready. A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves as
quality assurance verification that the prevention program requirements are properly implemented.
1.2.8	Mechanical Integrity
TETL has established practices and procedures for the secure operation of fixed, rotating, and emergency shutdown
equipment. The basic aspects of the program include, but are not limited to, the following:
	Conducting training
	Developing written procedures
	Performing examinations and tests
	Correcting identified deficiencies
	Applying quality assurance measures
These activities form a sys

tem to maintain process integrity. Maintenance personnel receive training on:
	Overview of the process
	Safety and health hazards
	Applicable maintenance procedures
	Emergency response plan
	Applicable secure work practices to help them to perform their jobs in a secure manner
Written procedures support consistent work performance and serve as a basis for training. Examinations and tests are
performed to help verify that equipment functions as intended, and that equipment is operating within acceptable limits. If a
deficiency is identified and the situation presents an immediate welfare concern, the deficiency is corrected before placing the
equipment back into service. The management team reviews the status of the equipment and determines what further action is
necessary.
An integral part of the integrity program is quality assurance. TETL incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment
purchases and repairs. This helps to determine that new equipment is applicable for its intended use and that the proper
materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made.
1.2.9	Safe Work Practices
TETL has standing safe work practices as mandated by OSHA, EPA, industrial standards, and good engineering practices in
place to help provide employee, public, and process safety.
1.2.10	Management of Change
TETL has a comprehensive system to manage changes to facility processes. This system requires that changes to items such
as process equipment, chemicals, technology, and procedures be properly reviewed and authorized before being
implemented. Each proposed change must be reviewed to:
	Determine that adequate equipment is in place to manage new hazards
	Verify that existing equipment has not been compromised by the proposed change
Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information and procedures are updated to
incorporate these changes. In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are trained on the changes.
1.2.11	Inciden

t Investigation
TETL promptly investigates each incident related to a covered process that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in a
fire/explosion, property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury. The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts
and develop recommendations to prevent future occurrences and forward these results to facility management for resolution.
Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation teams findings and recommendations are tracked until they are
concluded. The ultimate resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented and investigation reports are retained for
at least five years.
1.2.12	Compliance Audits
According to 40 CFR §68.79(a), TETL is required to conduct an audit every 3 years of the covered procedure to assess
compliance with the requirements of the prevention program. The audit must involve at least one individual who is
knowledgeable about the process. Good engineering practices are conducted by TETL employees and management, or a
qualified third-party, if appropriate. This audit team develops findings that are forwarded to facility management for resolution.
Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are concluded. The ultimate resolution
of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.
1.2.13	Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
TETL's accidental release prevention and response policies are applied to the entire RMP-covered process through universal
prevention activities, including but not limited to: elimination of sources of ignition, drains for liquid releases, and avoidance of
congested areas. Collectively, these prevention program activities help avoid potential accident scenarios that could be caused
by equipment failures and human errors.
1.2.14	Specialized Safety Features
Facility-specific detection and equipment (safety features) are deployed throughout the facility to:
	Contain/monitor a re

lease
	Quickly detect a release
	Reduce the consequences of an RMP-regulated substance releaseThe following type of safety features are operational at the facility:
	Release Detection
o	Level deviation alarm to notify the personnel if the surge tanks go over 90% operating capacity
o	Relief and Check Valves
o	A beacon for alarm state and visual driver notification for improper normal or Emergency Shutdown (ESD) System
o	Inspection of the couplers, hoses, and trucks during the unloading process by trained personnel to prevent leaks
	Release Mitigation
o	Fire extinguishers
o	Trained emergency response personnel
o	Personal protective equipment
1.2.15	Five-Year Accident History
The TETL rail car facility has had no RMP-regulated substance released during the past five years.
1.2.16	Emergency Response Program Information
The facility maintains a written emergency action plan, to help protect employees and public welfare as well as the
environment. The plan identifies steps to be taken in case of an accidental release, including first aid and medical treatment for
exposures; evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation; notification of local emergency response
agencies; and notification of the public if a release occurs.
TETL has around-the-clock communications capability, including deployment of emergency response personnel and
equipment with appropriate emergency response organizations (fire department, police, sheriff's office, or similar). This
interface provides the means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick responses to an
incident. In addition, TETL conducts regularly scheduled emergency drills and annual refresher training for facility personnel.
1.2.17	Planned Changes to Improve Safety
TETL's management is committed to the following:
	Preventing accidents
	Training employees in correct response procedures in the event of an accident
	Participating in community emergency preparedness trainin

g
	Addressing citizen concerns by explaining potential hazards associated with TETL operations and steps being taken to
prevent and mitigate accidents
With these objectives in mind, this Risk Management Plan has been developed to provide information about the management
of the risks associated with covered process.
